186.explanation: This direction activates on diverse common English words and phrases (War, catch, Mo, wait, oils, falls, prophecy, formula, down) that appear to be ordinary vocabulary tokens without a clear semantic theme.

187.label: Temporal delay or duration

188.label: Geographic location names
188.explanation: This direction activates strongly on proper nouns referring to specific geographic locations (countries, regions, cities, and places) that appear in bracketed positions within text.

189.label: Discourse topic shifts
189.explanation: This direction activates at points where the text abruptly transitions between unrelated topics or narratives, often marked by conjunctions or articles that bridge disparate subject matter.

190.label: Hyphenated compound adjectives
190.explanation: This direction activates on adjectives that are hyphenated or appear in compound modifier positions (hard-line, story-based, team-focused, single-player), capturing a grammatical pattern of multi-word descriptive phrases.

191.label: Parenthetical/contextual insertion
191.explanation: This direction activates on words that are inserted parenthetically or as clarifying asides within sentences, often appearing in brackets or as explanatory phrases that interrupt the main narrative flow.

192.label: Comparative/Contrastive discourse markers
192.explanation: This direction activates on words that introduce comparisons, contrasts, or qualifications between ideas or objects (more, suspiciously, interesting, sound, bit, readers, off-screen, tire, still, and).

194.label: Proper nouns and named entities
194.explanation: This direction activates strongly on specific proper nouns, brand names, and named entities (family, Honor, Polish, Gunners, etc.) that refer to particular people, places, organizations, or products.

195.label: Bracketed text fragments
195.explanation: This direction activates on isolated words or short phrases that appear to be randomly bracketed within longer text passages, with no clear semantic relationship to their surrounding context.

196.label: Middle name or patronymic
196.explanation: This direction activates on middle names, patronymic elements, or secondary name components that appear between first and last names or within biographical name structures.

197.label: Bracketed phrase emphasis
197.explanation: This direction activates on words or short phrases enclosed in brackets that are being highlighted or emphasized within the text, often marking key terms, concepts, or rhetorical points in the surrounding discourse.

198.label: Hedging/Qualification markers
198.explanation: This direction activates on words and phrases that introduce nuance, uncertainty, or qualification to preceding statements (roots, harmless, nuanced, seem, one, mark, hate, MB, seem, harmless), often softening or complicating claims.

199.label: Date/Number Range Boundaries
199.explanation: This direction activates strongly on the end dates or final numbers in date ranges and time periods (e.g., 'July 8', 'June 24', 'February 28', '6:03.98'), capturing the closing boundary of temporal or numerical intervals.

12.label: Large monetary amounts
12.explanation: This direction activates strongly on tokens that appear in contexts describing large sums of money (billion, trillion, million dollars, etc.), typically used to quantify significant financial figures, costs, or investments.

342.label: Part of phrase

354.label: Dog-related content
354.explanation: This direction activates strongly on tokens that are part of dog-related contexts, including dog breeds, dog products, dog behaviors, and dog-related news stories.

387.label: Universal quantifier or totality

770.label: Conjunction 'and' token

918.label: Compound noun phrases
918.explanation: This direction activates on multi-word noun phrases or compound terms that are typically hyphenated or written as two words (grocery, network, charge, dispensing, transport, search, noise, transportation, distribution, health), often appearing in technical, commercial, or descriptive contexts.

921.explanation: This direction activates on the equals sign (=) when used in assignment statements, parameter assignments, or key-value pairs across various contexts including shell commands, URLs, code, and configuration settings.

946.label: Coordinating conjunction 'and'

1083.explanation: This direction activates on question marks that function as rhetorical devices to engage readers or introduce topics, typically appearing at the beginning of sentences or paragraphs to draw attention.

1420.label: Transition to new topic

1499.label: Proper name boundaries
1499.explanation: This direction activates at points where proper names (surnames, place names) are being split or where name tokens appear, particularly at morpheme boundaries within surnames.

1548.explanation: This direction activates on mentions of government payments, benefits, and financial entitlements including pensions, bonuses, taxes, visas, child benefits, and student loans.

1791.label: Prefix 're-' token

2188.label: Negation or impossibility
2188.explanation: This direction activates strongly on the word 'impossible' and related expressions of negation, infeasibility, or logical contradiction across diverse contexts.

2204.label: Possession/Inclusion Verbs
2204.explanation: This direction activates on auxiliary and main verbs that express possession, inclusion, or composition (has, includes, comes with, with, a), typically used to describe what features or components something contains.

2540.label: Arrival or reaching destination
2540.explanation: This direction consistently activates on the word 'arrive' and its variants (arrived, arrive, arriving) across diverse contexts including travel narratives, work commutes, sports events, and temporal descriptions.

2575.label: Series introduction phrase

2585.label: Creating/Establishing Conditions

2609.label: Appearance or seeming
2609.explanation: This direction activates on the word 'seem' and its variants (seems, seemed) which express appearance, perception, or likelihood rather than certainty.

2776.label: Crime/Legal Charges
2776.explanation: This direction activates on words and phrases that describe criminal charges, legal offenses, and criminal conduct in news reporting contexts.

2825.label: Question word 'where'
2825.explanation: This direction strongly activates on the word 'where' (or 'Where') when it appears as an interrogative pronoun introducing questions about location, direction, or source.

2961.label: Conditional/hypothetical statements
2961.explanation: This direction activates on modal constructions expressing conditional, hypothetical, or counterfactual scenarios, particularly 'would' and 'd' contractions that indicate what might happen or what someone might do under certain conditions.

3088.label: Manila/Philippines location marker
3088.explanation: This direction activates strongly on tokens that are part of or immediately adjacent to 'Manila' or 'Philippines' references, typically appearing in datelines and geographic identifiers in news articles.

3238.explanation: This direction activates on individual items within enumerated lists, categories, or series (Twitter, broadcast, transport, Fair, anger, fear, hatred, salt), particularly when they appear as comma-separated or line-separated elements in a structured list.

3261.explanation: This direction activates on tokens appearing in contexts discussing deaths, tragic incidents, and expressions of grief or loss (e.g., 'missed', 'mourning', 'saddened', 'died', 'passing').

3280.explanation: This direction activates on the second or final part of multi-word proper names, particularly surnames, institutional names, and geographic locations (Johns, Sr, Loubriel, Maximilian, Ogawa, Bohr, McCrary, etc.).

3485.label: Software/Tool Names
3485.explanation: This direction activates on proper nouns referring to specific software applications and tools (Excel, GIMP, NX, Eclipse, Word, Solidworks, Photoshop, Acrobat Reader), typically appearing in technical or instructional contexts.

3524.label: Emergence or appearance
3524.explanation: This direction activates on the phrasal verb 'come out' and similar expressions indicating emergence, appearance, or coming forth from a location or state.

3536.label: Chemical/Medical compound suffixes
3536.explanation: This direction activates on the final syllables or morphemes of chemical compounds, drug names, and medical/scientific terminology (tianeptine, sulforaphane, alcid, OptoA2AR, COMAS, trimethylaminuria, NAc).

3540.label: Adverbial frequency/typicality markers
3540.explanation: This direction activates on adverbs like 'Usually', 'Typically', and 'usually' that indicate how commonly or generally something occurs or is done.

3543.label: Economic hardship/adversity
3543.explanation: This direction activates on phrases describing difficult economic conditions, financial struggles, or challenging times (hard times, tough economy, recession, economic upheaval, difficult financial climate).

3768.label: Discourse transition marker
3768.explanation: This direction activates on the word 'about' when it appears at a discourse boundary, typically introducing a new topic, interview subject, or shift in conversational focus within a text.

3948.label: Discourse marker 'Much'
3948.explanation: This direction activates on the word 'Much' when used as a discourse marker or quantifier at the beginning of clauses (e.g., 'Much of', 'Much like', 'Much better'), typically introducing comparative or descriptive statements.

4057.label: Photography and image capture
4057.explanation: This direction activates on words and phrases related to taking, making, or capturing photographs and images, including terms like 'photo', 'pictures', 'photographed', 'shots', and 'shot'.

4184.label: Organizational/workplace context
4184.explanation: This direction activates on tokens that appear in contexts describing companies, offices, workplaces, and organizational settings, often appearing near words like 'office', 'company', 'culture', 'organization', and 'hiring'.

4311.label: Sentence boundary / paragraph break
4311.explanation: This direction activates at points where text transitions between distinct topics, quotes, or narrative sections, typically marked by a line break or new paragraph in news articles.

4483.label: Preposition 'on/at/the' tokens
4483.explanation: This direction activates on common prepositions and articles (on, the, at, near) that appear in descriptive passages, particularly in spatial or locational contexts within longer text sequences.

4492.label: Collaborative effort or cooperation
4492.explanation: This direction activates on instances of 'work' or 'working' in contexts emphasizing collaboration, teamwork, joint effort, or people working together toward shared goals.

4748.label: Biographical fact insertion
4748.explanation: This direction activates at points where factual biographical information (birth dates, professions, achievements, or key life events) is being inserted or stated about a person, typically marked by punctuation or structural breaks in the text.

4927.label: Hello world / introductory examples
4927.explanation: This direction activates on tokens that appear in 'hello world' phrases and basic programming introductory examples, particularly in contexts teaching beginners how to write their first code.

4998.label: First-person perspective markers
4998.explanation: This direction activates on first-person pronouns and perspective indicators (I, we, you) that signal the speaker's personal viewpoint or subjective experience in narrative text.

5038.label: Wikipedia disambiguation redirect syntax
5038.explanation: This direction activates on the characteristic pattern of Wikipedia disambiguation page redirects, marked by text in brackets like '[musician]', '[song]', '[restaurant]', '[footballer]', '[disambiguation]' that clarify which meaning of an ambiguous term is being referenced.

5048.label: Specific location or entity
5048.explanation: This direction activates on concrete nouns referring to particular places, facilities, or institutions (brain, facility, base, town, film, sound, crossing, town, firm, supplement) that are mentioned as specific entities within their contexts.

5265.label: Discourse transition marker
5265.explanation: This direction activates on 'The' at the beginning of sentences that introduce a new claim, argument, or perspective shift in expository writing.

5530.label: Physical damage or malfunction
5530.explanation: This direction activates on tokens describing damage, breakage, injury, or mechanical failure affecting physical objects or bodies.

5595.label: Linguistic/orthographic exceptions
5595.explanation: This direction activates on tokens that appear in contexts discussing unusual spelling rules, pronunciation quirks, or exceptions to standard linguistic conventions across different languages and writing systems.

5759.label: Professional adjective usage
5759.explanation: This direction activates on the word 'professional' when used as an adjective to describe roles, standards, organizations, or expertise (e.g., 'professional poker star', 'professional standards', 'professional analysis').

6056.label: Common function words
6056.explanation: This direction activates on frequent, grammatically essential words (the, a, it, if, I, inside, up, along) that appear across diverse contexts with no semantic coherence.

6286.label: List item enumeration
6286.explanation: This direction activates on the final item in a comma-separated list, typically marked by 'and' before the last element in sequences of places, people, or entities.

6321.label: URL/hyperlink tokens
6321.explanation: This direction activates strongly on tokens that are part of or immediately precede URLs and hyperlinks (indicated by :// or similar URL syntax patterns).

6917.label: Numeric values in text
6917.explanation: This direction activates on numbers embedded within text passages, particularly multi-digit numbers that appear in various contexts (ages, specifications, measurements, years).

7122.label: Medical surgery/procedures
7122.explanation: This direction activates on words and contexts related to surgical operations, medical procedures, and recovery from surgery, including terms like 'operating table', 'surgery', 'surgically', 'operations', and 'operated'.

7289.label: Challenging/Difficult Terrain
7289.explanation: This direction activates on adjectives describing physically difficult or hazardous environmental conditions (rough, uneven, confined, wet, curvy, sensitive, busy, dark, rocky) that present obstacles or challenges for navigation, movement, or operation.

7293.label: Spatial location prepositions
7293.explanation: This direction activates on prepositions indicating spatial relationships or locations (of, in, on, inside) that connect nouns to their spatial context or container.

7470.label: Financial costs and expenditures
7470.explanation: This direction activates on words related to money spent, costs, or financial outlays across various contexts including business expenses, campaign spending, consumer expenditures, and personal costs.

7804.label: Conditional clause marker

7811.label: Declarative statement opening
7811.explanation: This direction activates on the phrase 'This is' when used to introduce a declarative statement, assertion, or claim about a situation, person, or concept.

7820.label: Second-person pronoun object
7820.explanation: This direction activates on the token 'you' or 'us' when used as the direct object of verbs in instructional or informative contexts (e.g., 'give you', 'show us', 'take you').

8032.explanation: This direction activates on tokens that represent partial or split words, typically appearing in the middle of compound words or where text segmentation creates unusual token boundaries (e.g., 'iph' in Ciphrex, 'equ' in equinepalette, 'Phot' in Photokina).

8229.label: Appositive or clarifying phrase
8229.explanation: This direction activates on tokens that introduce or follow explanatory phrases, parenthetical information, or clarifications that provide additional context about a preceding noun or concept.

8403.label: Negation token 'not'
8403.explanation: This direction consistently activates on the word 'not' across diverse contexts, capturing the linguistic negation operator regardless of semantic domain.

8636.label: Opposite/Antonym Pairs
8636.explanation: This direction activates on words that represent opposite or complementary concepts, such as 'lowered' (opposite of raised), 'falls' (opposite of rises), 'destroyed' (opposite of created), 'out' (opposite of in), and 'bust' (opposite of boom).

8881.label: Physical location/room reference
8881.explanation: This direction activates on tokens that reference specific physical spaces or rooms where actions occur (shelf, closet, dock, gym, lounge, lab, bus, stage, bathroom, pantry).

8964.label: Colon introducing explanation
8964.explanation: This direction activates on colons that introduce or precede explanatory clauses, elaborations, or clarifications that expand on the preceding statement.

8971.label: Sentence-ending punctuation
8971.explanation: This direction activates strongly on periods and conjunctions that appear at or near the end of sentences, particularly marking transitions between clauses or sentences.

9103.label: Epistemic surprise/discovery
9103.explanation: This direction activates on expressions of unexpected learning or realization, where the speaker discovers something they didn't previously know or expect (marked by phrases like 'didn't know', 'never thought', 'who knew', 'I thought').

9322.label: Detection and discovery
9322.explanation: This direction activates on words related to identifying, discovering, or finding something (detect, detection, detecting) across diverse contexts including security, science, technology, and investigation.

9364.label: Period-ending sentence boundaries

9812.label: Curiosity or questioning

10050.label: Legal/Court Context

10110.label: Possessive pronoun 'your'
10110.explanation: This direction consistently activates on the possessive pronoun 'your' (and its variant 'your' in different contexts), which appears in phrases like 'your favorite,' 'your average,' 'your crowdfunding campaign,' and 'your own workout experiences.'

10317.explanation: This direction activates on words that introduce or continue lists of items, such as 'were', 'workers', 'right', 'order', 'are', 'Studies', 'by', and 'R', which typically appear when enumerating multiple entities or presenting sequential information.

10729.label: Ellipsis or text truncation
10729.explanation: This direction activates strongly at points where text is interrupted, cut off, or continues with ellipses (...), dashes (—), or brackets ([...]), indicating narrative breaks or incomplete statements in the source material.

11005.label: Professional role/occupation
11005.explanation: This direction activates on tokens that complete or describe specific professional roles, job titles, and occupational categories (graphic-designing, management, design, technology, operations, development, etc.).

11099.label: Narrative subject description
11099.explanation: This direction activates on prepositions and verbs that introduce what a story, film, or work is fundamentally about (about, of, details, tracks, follow, etc.), marking the transition to describing the core subject matter or plot.

11188.explanation: This direction activates on specialized domain-specific terms that appear in technical, medical, or scientific contexts (neurological, cytokine, VPN, mining, seizures, jailbreak, LNG, overflow, memory, ionisation).

11307.explanation: This direction activates on prepositions that indicate time or sequence (the, of, minutes) appearing in sports narrative contexts, particularly before temporal markers or action descriptions.

11435.explanation: This direction activates on tokens that separate or connect numbers in ranges (like 'to' in '20 to 25' or hyphens/dashes in '6-9'), marking the boundary between two quantities in a span or interval.

11978.explanation: This direction activates on nouns or noun phrases that complete or specify what precedes them, often appearing after descriptive modifiers or in contexts where the noun provides concrete instantiation of an abstract concept.

12386.label: Separation/Distance/Relocation
12386.explanation: This direction activates on tokens describing physical separation, travel, relocation, or the challenges of being apart from someone or somewhere due to geographic distance or job requirements.

13278.explanation: This direction activates on adjectives followed by commas and coordinating conjunctions (primarily 'and'), typically in descriptive phrases where two qualities are listed together.

13709.explanation: This direction consistently activates on the word 'obtained' when used in passive voice constructions (e.g., 'has obtained', 'was obtained', 'obtained through'), indicating detection of a specific grammatical pattern rather than semantic content.

14778.label: Punctuation before clause

15438.explanation: This direction activates on rhetorical questions and tag questions (right?, yes?, didn't it?, does it?) that are used to engage readers or seek agreement on a point just made.

15583.label: Explanatory clause introduction

15804.label: Parenthetical/bracketed clarifications

16570.label: Indefinite article 'a'

16839.label: Corporate values and mission statements

18413.explanation: This direction activates at points where text transitions between different narrative contexts, speakers, or quoted passages, often marking shifts from one story or speaker to another.

19586.explanation: This direction activates on words that describe or categorize organizations, groups, and institutions (sector, center, door, group, organizations, charity), typically appearing in contexts where an organization's type, role, or affiliation is being specified.

19715.explanation: This direction activates on tokens that complete or specify noun phrases, typically single words that follow descriptive context and provide concrete nouns (dopamine, CO2, euro, kindness, C, cigarette, rent, square, Mandarin, Higgs).

20853.explanation: This direction activates on feminine articles and determiners in Romance languages (Portuguese 'a', Italian 'le', Spanish 'la', 'na') that precede feminine nouns.

22188.explanation: This direction activates on contractions and auxiliary verbs in first-person plural contexts (we've, we're, we had, we have, we got, we showed), particularly at the point where the contraction or auxiliary verb appears in the text.

23239.explanation: This direction activates on adjectives and descriptive modifiers that characterize or qualify nouns (Android, polar, Japanese, free, 3D, my, pattern), particularly when they appear in technical or informational contexts.

24037.explanation: This direction activates on words that introduce or connect descriptive phrases and clauses (you, tells, in, analysis, technique, the, -, has, been, that), particularly those that precede explanatory or qualifying information about nouns.

24659.label: Verb usage or invocation
24659.explanation: This direction activates on verbs and verbal constructions that involve invoking, using, saying, or referencing something (used, invoked, say, for, of, using, invoking, onto, to, in), particularly in contexts where ideas, concepts, or principles are being called upon or applied.

24695.label: Sentence continuation/transition
24695.explanation: This direction activates at punctuation marks and conjunctions that connect or continue sentences, particularly periods, commas, and words like 'Also', 'As', 'The', 'and' that bridge between clauses or introduce new information.

24925.label: Preposition 'of/on/for'
24925.explanation: This direction activates strongly on prepositions that introduce relationships between entities, particularly 'of', 'on', and 'for' which connect nouns or indicate possession, involvement, or purpose.

25618.label: Testing/Experimentation Action
25618.explanation: This direction activates on the verb 'test' (and its variants like 'testing') when used to describe conducting experiments, trials, or evaluations of products, systems, or capabilities.

26113.label: Experience-based credibility
26113.explanation: This direction activates when speakers establish personal experience or expertise as a basis for their authority or perspective on a topic.

26299.label: Prepositional phrase continuations
26299.explanation: This direction activates on tokens that complete prepositional phrases or locative/temporal expressions, such as 'out in', 'in Moab', 'conditions', 'games', 'time is', 'exclusively', 'them out', and 'up'.

26754.label: Sharing or distributing content
26754.explanation: This direction activates strongly on phrases involving sharing, distributing, or communicating information/content with others, typically using prepositions like 'with' or 'to' that indicate transfer of knowledge or resources.

27769.label: Attribution/Source introduction
27769.explanation: This direction activates on tokens that introduce or connect quoted statements to their speakers or sources, typically appearing in the pattern of 'said [token] Name/Title' or similar attribution structures in news articles.

28209.label: Syllable boundary disruption
28209.explanation: This direction activates when a word is split mid-syllable or mid-morpheme, with the bracketed token representing the second part of a fragmented word (rub[bed], Kab[ula], Ub[iquiti], Kab[uki], Kab[yle], rab[id], Nab[isco], etc.).

30389.label: Possessive pronoun articles
30389.explanation: This direction activates on the tokens 'a', 'her', 'the', and 'my' that appear immediately before or after possessive constructions or articles introducing noun phrases with possessive relationships.

30951.label: Vehicle/Product Introduction
30951.explanation: This direction activates on tokens that introduce or describe the defining characteristics, creation, or significance of vehicles and machines (cars, aircraft, motorcycles), typically marking the beginning of descriptive or historical statements about them.

31430.label: News source attribution
31430.explanation: This direction activates on news organization names and media outlets cited as sources for reported information, typically appearing in phrases like '[Publication] reported' or '[News outlet] discovered'.

31967.label: Proper nouns in brackets
31967.explanation: This direction activates on proper nouns (names of people, places, organizations, publications, venues) that appear in square brackets within text.

33036.label: Contrastive comparison markers
33036.explanation: This direction activates on words that introduce contrasts, comparisons, or shifts in perspective (bigger, different, a, very, no, wrong, more), often appearing in contexts where the text pivots to present an alternative viewpoint or unexpected information.

33888.label: Destruction/Harm language
33888.explanation: This direction activates on words and phrases related to destruction, damage, or harm - including literal destruction (buildings, structures), metaphorical destruction (trust, heritage), and threats of destruction (military/political contexts).

34713.label: Comparative quantity/degree expressions
34713.explanation: This direction activates on words that express comparative states, quantities, or degrees in contexts where something is being measured, evaluated, or contrasted against a standard or alternative.

36421.label: Adjectives describing internal/hidden qualities
36421.explanation: This direction activates on adjectives that describe things that are internal, concealed, underlying, or not immediately apparent (spurious, initial, sinking, retro, civilized, innermost, healthy, inner, jerk, pent-up).

36714.label: Cast list separator punctuation
36714.explanation: This direction activates on commas and conjunctions that separate actor names in film/TV cast listings, appearing consistently between cast members' names.

37482.label: Criminal conspiracy language
37482.explanation: This direction activates on words related to conspiracy, plotting, or coordinated illegal activities, appearing consistently in news headlines about criminal charges and investigations.

37630.label: Time notation digits
37630.explanation: This direction activates on individual digits that appear within time stamps and temporal notations (hours, minutes, seconds) in published article metadata.

38067.label: Stick/Sticking verb usage
38067.explanation: This direction activates on various forms and contexts of the verb 'stick' (stick, sticking, stuck) across different grammatical and semantic uses including phrasal verbs, literal actions, and idiomatic expressions.

41303.label: Biographical achievement summary
41303.explanation: This direction activates on tokens that appear in biographical passages describing professional accomplishments, credentials, and notable roles (contributions to publications, board memberships, awards, career positions).

41389.label: List item headers/labels
41389.explanation: This direction activates on words that introduce or label items in a list or enumerated sequence (Lesson, Reason, Tip, Activities, Updates, The), typically appearing before numbered or bulleted content.

41442.label: Collective noun phrases
41442.explanation: This direction activates on noun phrases that refer to groups of people using collective terms like 'women', 'folks', 'people', 'students', 'researchers', 'experts', and 'engineers'.

44439.label: Collaborative partnership preposition
44439.explanation: This direction activates on the preposition 'with' when it appears in contexts describing partnerships, collaborations, meetings, or working relationships between entities.

44921.label: Sports team gender/category
44921.explanation: This direction activates on gendered sports terminology (boys, men's, girls, women's) and sport-specific nouns that categorize athletic teams and competitions.

49394.label: Copula verb 'is/are'
49394.explanation: This direction activates on the copula verbs 'is', 'are', 'that', and 'which' - linking verbs and relative pronouns that connect subjects to predicates or introduce descriptive clauses.

49959.label: Direct address to reader
49959.explanation: This direction activates on tokens that are part of phrases directly addressing or acknowledging the reader/audience (e.g., 'you', 'here', 'thank you', 'welcome you', 'arrived here'), typically found in introductory or welcoming text sections.

50574.label: Passive voice or past participle
50574.explanation: This direction activates on past participle verbs and passive voice constructions (died, was, shared, arrested, removed, took place, fell, moves) that describe completed actions or state changes.

50943.label: Metadata/Attribution markers
50943.explanation: This direction activates on punctuation and short words that appear in metadata contexts, citations, and attributions (commas, 'in', 'an', 'of', 'University', 'German', 'Thomas'), particularly at boundaries between content sections or before proper nouns/titles.

51949.label: Year/Date tokens
51949.explanation: This direction activates on the '0' digit within year numbers (2[0]02, 2[0]08, 2[0]10, 2[0]06, 2[0]07, 2[0]13, 2[0]08), consistently firing on the middle digit of four-digit years in the 2000s-2010s range.

52506.label: Temporal progression or emergence
52506.explanation: This direction activates on words describing things that develop, appear, or move forward in time (trends, emerge, appear, takes, involve), capturing the concept of change, progression, or things coming into being.

53412.label: Quoted or reported speech
53412.explanation: This direction activates on tokens that introduce or are part of direct quotations, reported dialogue, or speech attribution patterns (e.g., 'it', 'explained', 'the', quotation marks, colons before speech).

54183.label: Institutional/organizational location
54183.explanation: This direction activates on nouns referring to specific institutions, organizations, or geographic locations (church, college, brewery, campaign, police, Maryland) that serve as contextual anchors in news and informational text.

54294.label: Collaborative/Joint Undertaking
54294.explanation: This direction activates on words describing collaborative efforts, partnerships, or joint initiatives (project, initiative, organized, sponsored, partnership) where multiple entities or groups work together on an event or endeavor.

55209.label: Athletic performance quality
55209.explanation: This direction activates on words and phrases describing how well athletes or teams are performing, including terms like 'form', 'breakout', 'well', 'run', 'performance', 'fine', 'flourished', and 'poor form'.

59382.label: Apostrophe contractions
59382.explanation: This direction activates on contractions formed with apostrophes, particularly negative contractions like "didn't", "aren't", and possessive contractions like "city's", "theatre's", "England's", and "1980s".

63180.label: Famous person name tokens
63180.explanation: This direction activates strongly on tokens that are parts of well-known celebrity and public figure names (Kobe, Kanye, Xi, LeBron, Joffrey, Oprah), particularly when they appear in contexts discussing these individuals.

64670.label: Job title/position prepositions
64670.explanation: This direction activates on prepositions and function words that appear in job title constructions, particularly 'of', 'as', 'VP', and 'president' when describing someone's professional role or position.

65868.label: Auxiliary verb usage
65868.explanation: This direction activates on auxiliary verbs (has, his, is, have, always, chose, took, take, to, does) that appear in various grammatical contexts within news and informational text.

67295.label: Punctuation and formatting tokens
67295.explanation: This direction activates on various punctuation marks, numbers, and special characters that serve as structural delimiters in text (apostrophes, hyphens, commas, brackets, numbers in dates/ratings).

68112.label: City location mentions
68112.explanation: This direction activates strongly on city names that appear in bracketed positions, typically marking geographic locations where significant events, meetings, or announcements occur.

68186.label: Predictive/Speculative Language
68186.explanation: This direction activates on modal verbs and auxiliary words that express prediction, speculation, or conditional statements (will, if, that, not, see, duty) used to introduce uncertain future outcomes or hypothetical scenarios.

71182.label: Quote or statement introduction
71182.explanation: This direction activates at the beginning of quoted speech or attributed statements, typically marked by first-person pronouns or demonstrative words ('The', 'This', 'I', 'A') that introduce a speaker's direct words or thoughts.

71245.label: Narrative transition or shift
71245.explanation: This direction activates at points where the text transitions between different topics, introduces new information, or marks a shift in narrative direction (e.g., 'DNA' introducing genetic explanation, 'you' shifting to direct address, 'said' introducing reported speech, 'country' shifting context, 'people' generalizing scope, 'into' indicating direction change, 'changed' marking a turning point, 'announced' introducing news, 'woman' introducing a subject, 'million' introducing a specific detail).

71340.label: Preposition and function words
71340.explanation: This direction activates on common prepositions and function words (of, for, with, a, the, changed) that serve grammatical roles rather than carrying primary semantic content.

71438.label: Physical or visual motion
71438.explanation: This direction activates on the word 'motion' or 'movement' when referring to physical movement, animation, kinetic action, or visual dynamics rather than abstract social/political movements.

79388.label: Plural noun phrases
79388.explanation: This direction activates on plural nouns or noun phrases that follow descriptive modifiers, often appearing in contexts where groups, collections, or multiple entities are being referenced.

82846.label: Product/Model Names
82846.explanation: This direction activates on specific product model numbers and technical identifiers (Android 4.4, Xeon E5, Exmor, Marvell, Cartosat-2, asteroid 2012, EK-XRES, Jetson) that appear in technical and product review contexts.

83135.label: Brand/Company Names
83135.explanation: This direction activates on proper nouns referring to commercial businesses, retail chains, and corporate entities (Dave & Buster's, Hamburger Mary's, Trader Joe's, Whole Foods, Woolworths, etc.).

85460.label: Auxiliary verb tokens
85460.explanation: This direction activates on auxiliary verbs and modal verbs (will, is, to, would, ability, report, experts) that appear in sentence continuations and grammatical constructions.

85771.label: Prepositional phrase boundaries
85771.explanation: This direction activates at the boundaries between prepositions and their objects or complements (on/by/in/of), marking transitions in grammatical structure within noun phrases and clauses.

91159.label: Clarification or parenthetical insertion
91159.explanation: This direction activates on tokens that introduce clarifications, corrections, or parenthetical asides that disambiguate or provide additional context about preceding statements.

91434.label: Numerical digit tokens
91434.explanation: This direction activates strongly on individual digit characters (0-9) appearing in various contexts including statistics, scores, numbers, and numerical data.

93234.label: Temporal/Date Information
93234.explanation: This direction activates on tokens that are part of or immediately follow temporal expressions, including specific dates (years like 1925, 1924, 1912), time periods (days, PM), and temporal markers (today, WHEN).

97319.label: Name fragments or partial names
97319.explanation: This direction activates on partial or fragmented personal names that appear mid-word or in unusual contexts, such as 'Crisp[ino]', 'Edward', 'Ald[rin]', 'Shamsub[ahr]in', 'Dolan', 'Th[rin]', 'Hillary', 'Z[ena]ida', and 'Johnny [Kre]ysen'.

97651.label: Preposition 'for' token
97651.explanation: This direction consistently activates on the word 'for' used as a preposition indicating purpose, destination, or intended recipient in various contexts.

99942.label: Pronoun or auxiliary verb
99942.explanation: This direction activates on pronouns (it, it) and auxiliary verbs (has, also, is, app) that appear in the middle of sentences, particularly in contexts where they serve as connectors or subject references in compound clauses.

103932.label: Reported discovery or finding
103932.explanation: This direction activates on verbs and phrases that indicate something was discovered, revealed, confirmed, or found out through investigation or reporting (deputies, confirmed, showed, concludes, show, claim, found, fears, certain, out).

104064.label: Causal explanation or consequence
104064.explanation: This direction activates on tokens that introduce or follow causal relationships, explanations of why something happens, or consequences of prior statements.

105942.label: Seeking safety/protection
105942.explanation: This direction activates on tokens related to people taking refuge, seeking shelter, or moving to safety during dangerous or chaotic situations.

109848.label: Conditional/hypothetical framing
109848.explanation: This direction activates on words that introduce conditional statements, hypothetical scenarios, or subjunctive mood constructions (if, you're, re, who, Perhaps, When, s) that set up speculative or contingent situations in narrative text.

129713.label: Progressive/Liberal activism
129713.explanation: This direction activates on tokens associated with progressive political causes, social justice advocacy, woke culture, and left-leaning activism, often appearing in contexts discussing political correctness, environmental causes, human rights, and social change initiatives.

131429.label: Narrative transition or setup
131429.explanation: This direction activates at points where a new narrative thread, character perspective, or contextual shift is introduced, typically marked by a proper noun or character name followed by descriptive action or statement that establishes context for what follows.

133489.label: Subject-verb transition
133489.explanation: This direction activates at the boundary where a named entity (proper noun) transitions into a verb phrase, typically marking the shift from subject to predicate in sentences beginning with 'X has/does/makes/had'.

135046.label: Nationality/Group identifiers
135046.explanation: This direction activates on adjectives and nouns that identify people by their national, ethnic, or group affiliation (Union, Ukrainian, Russian, Israeli, Serb, bull terrier, drone), particularly in contexts describing conflict, violence, or group-based actions.

136275.label: US state capital city names
136275.explanation: This direction activates strongly on tokens that are US state capital city names (OLYMPIA, TRENTON, ALBANY, SPRINGFIELD) appearing in news article datelines and location headers.

143446.label: Government ministry references
143446.explanation: This direction activates on mentions of specific government departments and their officials (Interior, Defence, Commerce, Home, Safety, Justice, Finance ministries), typically appearing in news contexts where these agencies are making statements or taking action.

149259.label: Legal/Ownership Claims
149259.explanation: This direction activates on words related to legal rights, ownership, claims, and relationships—particularly in contexts discussing proprietary interests, contractual rights, and formal assertions of entitlement or connection.

165494.label: Court jurisdiction specification
165494.explanation: This direction activates on prepositions and articles that introduce or specify the geographic jurisdiction of courts (e.g., 'for the Fourth Circuit', 'for the D.C. Circuit', 'for the Eastern District'), particularly in legal contexts describing appellate and district courts.

174417.label: Simulation/Mimicry verbs
174417.explanation: This direction activates on verbs and related words that describe simulating, mimicking, or replicating something (simulate, mimic, experience, could face), particularly in contexts where artificial conditions or systems are designed to replicate real-world phenomena.

182256.label: Text fragment boundaries
182256.explanation: This direction activates at points where text segments are spliced together or where there are discontinuities in narrative flow, often marked by bracketed tokens that appear to be insertion points or editorial markers in concatenated text.

184431.label: First names in text
184431.explanation: This direction activates on common first names (Harvey, Lincoln, Jordan, Duke, Clare, Preston, Ian, Bethany) that appear in the middle of sentences or text passages.

193286.label: Lifting/Removing Restrictions
193286.explanation: This direction activates on tokens describing the removal, easing, or lifting of constraints, sanctions, blockades, sieges, or restrictions imposed on entities (countries, regions, or groups).

196557.label: Fictional character names
196557.explanation: This direction activates on proper names of characters from fictional universes (Star Trek, Marvel, Star Wars, Game of Thrones, Breaking Bad, Doctor Who, The Hobbit), typically appearing in contexts where they are referenced or mentioned.

207652.label: Negative reaction/backlash source
207652.explanation: This direction activates when text describes criticism, complaints, outrage, or negative responses directed at someone or something, typically introduced by phrases like 'from' that indicate the source of disapproval.

219654.label: Preposition tokens
219654.explanation: This direction activates on common prepositions (to, for, as, more, of, :, include) that appear in various grammatical contexts throughout text.

230543.label: Discourse marker/connector tokens
230543.explanation: This direction activates on short function words and prepositions (key, story, years, of, with, the, five, renewing) that serve as connective or structural elements between clauses or phrases in text.

242420.label: Photo credit/attribution text
242420.explanation: This direction activates on photo credits, image attributions, and mandatory credit lines that appear in news articles and media content.
